title: 105_hr3166
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Employees Health Care Freedom of Choice Act" and includes amendments to Title 5 of the United States Code. The Act, titled the "Federal Employees Health Care Freedom of Choice Act," amends Title 5 of the United States Code by defining terms like "high deductible health plan" and "medical savings account." It also grants the Office authority to contract for high deductible health plans with qualified carriers. The Federal Employees Health Care Freedom of Choice Act allows the Office to contract for high deductible health plans with qualified carriers, offering a choice of plans under specific criteria. The Federal Employees Health Care Freedom of Choice Act allows the Office to contract for high deductible health plans with qualified carriers, offering a choice of plans under specific criteria, including the types of benefits provided. This section does not restrict carriers from offering multiple plans simultaneously or require high deductible health plans to offer two levels of benefits. It also allows for the offering of multiple plans that satisfy the criteria outlined in the Act. The Federal Employees Health Care Freedom of Choice Act allows for the offering of multiple high deductible health plans that satisfy specific criteria outlined in the Act, including types of benefits provided. Amendments to Section 8904(a) of title 5, United States Code, allow for the inclusion of high deductible health plans with benefits named under specific subsections. Conforming amendments to other sections ensure that plans meeting certain requirements can be included. Amendments are made to various sections of title 5, United States Code, including changes to Section 8909(d) and contributions towards high deductible health plans and medical savings accounts. Section 8903 is also amended to include regulations for specific plan descriptions. Amendments to title 5, United States Code include redesignating section 8906a as section 8906b and adding a new section 8906a for contribution provisions related to individuals enrolled in high deductible health plans. The amount withheld from pay or annuity for these individuals is based on the difference between the average subscription charge and the provisions of section 8906(d). The Government contribution for the contract year cannot exceed 100 percent of the subscription charge for the plan. The biweekly contribution towards the subscription charge is the difference between the charge and the amount withheld from the employee's pay or annuity. The Government will pay the excess amount to the medical savings account of eligible employees or annuitants, in addition to the contribution under section 8906. Employees cannot decline these contributions. Contributions will not be made if the total Government contribution exceeds the required amount towards the subscription charge for the plan. The Office will regulate how employees or annuitants identify their medical savings accounts for contributions under this subsection. Adjustments in contribution amounts under section 8906 will take effect as required by subsections (b) or (c) of this section. Employees and annuitants must meet specific eligibility criteria for government contributions under section 8906. This section does not apply if the individual would not otherwise be eligible for a contribution. Additionally, subsections (b) and (c) do not apply if the individual is ineligible for a contribution or if the contribution amount would be zero. The Office will regulate the application of section 8906(c) to adjust individual to Government contribution ratios. The term 'total Government contribution allowable' refers to the maximum contribution for health benefits for an employee or annuitant in a contract year. Technical amendments are made to the table of sections in chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code. Title 5, United States Code, is amended by updating the item related to section 8906a. Section 8906 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to exclude high deductible health plans from government contributions. Additionally, a coordination provision is included to clarify the impact of these amendments. The amendment in this section affects the authority under section 1005(f) of title 39, US Code, regarding provisions in chapter 89 of title 5, US Code. A technical amendment is made to section 8909(a) of title 5, US Code. Section 8907 is amended to provide information to individuals eligible for government contributions to a medical savings account. The Office will provide information on Government contributions to medical savings accounts for employees and annuitants eligible for high deductible health plans. The amendments apply to contract years starting on or after January 1, 1999. Measures are in place to ensure coverage under a high deductible health plan as of the beginning of the first contract year. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1986. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include changes related to the inclusion of employees enrolled in FEHBP high deductible health plans and limitations on contributions limited to federal contributions. The limitation for any individual under the federal employee health benefits plan is zero if covered by a high deductible health plan. Numerical limitations do not apply to individuals entitled to receive annuity amounts. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include changes related to employees in FEHBP high deductible health plans. The new paragraph exempts individuals covered by federal employee health benefits plans from certain limitations on medical savings accounts. No reporting is required for accounts of individuals covered by these plans. The new paragraph exempts individuals covered by federal employee health benefits plans from limitations on medical savings accounts established at the time such individual was an eligible individual.
